hints.content:
###Standard equation of the circle

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.



[[☃ image 1]]

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

options.alt: A circle that is centered at point H, K. The radius, r, goes from the center at H, K to the edge of the circle at point X, Y. The radius is the hypotenuse in a right triangle. The base of the triangle is a horizontal dashed line that is labeled X minus H. The height of the triangle is a vertical dashed line that is labeled Y minus K.

hints.content:
### Finding the center and the radius

This is the given equation written in standard form:

$(x-(\blueE{-5}))^2+(y-(\maroonD{-2}))^2=\goldE{2}^2$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{-5},\maroonD{-2})$ and the radius is $\goldE{2}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{-5},\maroonD{-2})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE 2$.



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A circle that is centered at point H, K. The radius, r, goes from the center at H, K to the edge of the circle at point X, Y. The radius is the hypotenuse in a right triangle. The base of the triangle is a horizontal dashed line that is labeled X minus H. The height of the triangle is a vertical dashed line that is labeled Y minus K.

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A circle has a center of negative six, negative five and a radius of three units.

This is the given equation written in standard form:

$(x-\blueE{1})^2+(y-\maroonD{1})^2=\goldE{9}^2$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{1},\maroonD{1})$ and the radius is $\goldE{9}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{1},\maroonD{1})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE{9}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A circle has a center of one, one and a radius of nine units.

hints.content:
###Standard equation of the circle

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.



[[☃ image 1]]

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

options.alt: A circle that is centered at point H, K. The radius, r, goes from the center at H, K to the edge of the circle at point X, Y. The radius is the hypotenuse in a right triangle. The base of the triangle is a horizontal dashed line that is labeled X minus H. The height of the triangle is a vertical dashed line that is labeled Y minus K.

hints.content:
### Finding the center and the radius

This is the given equation written in standard form:

$(x-\blueE{0})^2+(y-\maroonD{5})^2=\goldE{5}^2$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{0},\maroonD{5})$ and the radius is $\goldE{5}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{0},\maroonD{5})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE{5}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A circle has a center of zero, five and a radius of five units.
